abstract.p: Liechestein's Assn of Banks will no longer permit anonymous or code-named bank accounts, a response to principality's inclusion in Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development's list of 15 money-laundering centers worldwide; holders of existing anonymous accounts will have grace period before they must come forward (M)

block.p: Simultaneously sustaining an air of rectitude and a tradition of banking secrecy is getting harder and harder.

At the end of June, when the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development published a roster of 15 money-laundering centers worldwide, it listed mainly familiar havens like the Bahamas and Panama. But there, too, was the tidy Alpine principality of Liechtenstein.
Simultaneously sustaining an air of rectitude and a tradition of banking secrecy is getting harder and harder.

At the end of June, when the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development published a roster of 15 money-laundering centers worldwide, it listed mainly familiar havens like the Bahamas and Panama. But there, too, was the tidy Alpine principality of Liechtenstein.

Discomfiture about the list and embarrassment over headlines about the country's unwitting role in the financial shenanigans of Russian mobsters have led Liechtenstein's Association of Banks to a policy innovation: henceforth, people who open accounts must say who they are.
Holders of existing anonymous or code-name accounts would get a grace period before they have to own up, an association spokesman told Agence France-Presse.
